column4: it is sorta like running a mini ircd that connects to freenode and then you connect your client to "your" server. when you disconnect your client the bnc keeps your nick online.
what's the benefit over screen and irssi?
you can also give accounts to other users to connect to the bnc
and will they be using your nick or one they setup?
their own nick
and can the others talk within themselves through the bnc without bouncing to freenode or whereever?
yes ZNC has that feature, I guess most bnc's have it
k.. guess I'm still missing the point of it other then a remote irc server that connects directly to an actual irc server..  I'll have to mull it over
basically let's say you wanted to give your customers a way of contacting you via irc you could setup the bnc to freenode and then have the bnc auto forward to #scunizi for example
so customers would connect to the bnc and it would relay to you nomatter what channel you're on?
or #scunizi would be an inhouse bnc server hosted channel even though nick scunizi is also connected to other channels?
not exactly. when they connect to the bnc they would be sent to #example. you would have to be in that #
from what I understand bnc's were used back in the day when networks didn't use nickserv.
and that's something you set within the bnc so when they connect they're routed directly to a specific channel you're monitoring?
and there is also the feature that when you reconnect your client you get a playback of what was said while you were gone.
yes the #example routing is set in the bnc
k.. starting to see the light :).. intersting..
we used to use bnc back when on EFnet. they didn't have nickserv ( not sure they do now )
old school stuff. I like it.. I use to run a part time BBS on a 1200baud modem :)
